I like sharp objects and cryptography, for which I have a Ph.D. (not in sharp objects).
‚öîÔ∏è
I enjoy working on secure messaging, privacy, and proofs of security.
Been getting into post-quantum lately.

I am currently a cryptographer at Quarkslab. I work on any part of our clients’ product’s life, giving advice on protocol choices during the design, auditing after it’s built, helping with choosing a new algorithm for updates (e.g. when transitioning to post-quantum), etc.
I also enjoy working on the blog as an editor/reviewer, sometimes writer. When I get the chance, I like to present my work either internally or more publicly.
Before Qb, I did a Ph.D. at the IRISA lab in Rennes, in what was then known as the EMSEC team, under supervision of Pierre-Alain Fouque and Cristina Onete. I worked on the security of so-called Real-World Protocols, such as TLS and Signal. Researching and writing on Signal made me very fond of secure messaging in general, which I still love today. ‚ô•Ô∏è

Thesis üìú # Provable security of real world protocols Provable security is a very useful cryptographic tool that helps in the evaluation of the security of a protocol. In order to construct a proof, one must first define the security properties that are to be achieved, i.e., the security model, as well as what kind of adversary we are facing. In this thesis, we introduce (or adapt) models in which we give security proofs for three kinds of protocols with real-life applications: a secure messaging protocol, a sanitizable signature, and a reverse firewall.
